sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Find the root of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 4x - 8 using the Newton-Raphson method correct to four decimal places, starting with an initial guess of x0 = 2.5.
message_2:
To apply the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 4x - 8. 

The derivative, f'(x), is given by:
f'(x) = 3x^2 - 4x + 4

Now, we can apply the Newton-Raphson formula, which is:
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)

Given the initial guess x0 = 2.5, we will find x1 and iterate until the result converges to four decimal places.

Iteration 1:
x0 = 2.5
f(x0) = (2.5)^3 - 2(2.5)^2 + 4(2.5) - 8 = 1.875
f'(x0) = 3(2.5)^2 - 4(2.5) + 4 = 11.5
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) = 2.5 - 1.875 / 11.5 ≈ 2.3369

Iteration 2:
x0 = 2.3369
f(x0) = (2.3369)^3 - 2(2.3369)^2 + 4(2.3369) - 8 ≈ 0.0552
f'(x0) = 3(2.3369)^2 - 4(2.3369) + 4 ≈ 10.7965
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) = 2.3369 - 0.0552 / 10.7965 ≈ 2.3316

Iteration 3:
x0 = 2.3316
f(x0) = (2.3316)^3 - 2(2.3316)^2 + 4(2.3316) - 8 ≈ 0.0003
f'(x0) = 3(2.3316)^2 - 4(2.3316) + 4 ≈ 10.7511
x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0) = 2.3316 - 0.0003 / 10.7511 ≈ 2.3315

The root of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + 4x - 8, using the Newton-Raphson method with an initial guess of x0 = 2.5, converges to 2.3315 (correct to four decimal places) after three iterations.
